children.subject:
But my point is it makes sense if you're EECS, since you'd be working with hardware, e.g. with robotics etc.

But it seems irrelevant and tangential to a CS degree. I disagree CS majors need to understand the lowest level of abstraction; logic gate level makes sense because it helps you understand assembly which is crucial. But EE16B level is just pushing the notion that because you're coding on a computer, you should know exactly how the innermost circuits work.

Point of majors is to let you choose courses that relate to the major, not force a restriction that isn't really related to the major. At least make it a choice between taking EE16B as a possible credit course for the major, but allowing other courses.

I disagree -- your premise is that CS majors don't need EE 16B, but I think the right step would be to have EECS majors need more than 16B. It's important to understand robotics, control theory, linear algebra, transistors, etc. for computer science. And although I agree with you that logic gates are a good lower bound for CS majors, in order to understand logic gates fully you need to understand that they are physical devices with non-idealities.

Linear algebra yes. Control theory, robotics, and transistors, for CS majors? I disagree. EECS majors makes sense because they go into the EE side of things, but CS doesn't have EE in its name. 

For your point about logic gates, yes you can get even deeper always, like understanding the physics behind circuits better and better. But it's not relevant to the computer science aspect of things - you can easily get away with abstracting away transistors for the vast majority of CS classes (not necessarily EECS classes). All I'm arguing is that there is a difference between EECS and CS, and having EE16B be a requirement for CS and not just EECS seems forceful and unnecessary.

Well...Not all EECS majors even explore the EE side. In fact I'd say most EECS majors do no more EE-side classes than your typical CS major. And additionally there's always a few CS majors who decide to specialize in EE—they aren't really different majors, it's more like EECS is "CoE CS" and CS is "L&S EECS."

Well that's up to the EECS majors, but if your major has EE in it, it fundamentally makes sense to require an intro EE class like EE16B. If CS majors decide to specialize in EE that's fine as well. The two majors are described differently - just because they happen to converge to be more CS and less EE, doesn't mean the requirements should conform to that. In any case, I don't think those undermine my point of saying EE16B shouldn't be required for CS majors.

I feel like it's important for CS majors to understand a little bit about the hardware that they are programming on, 1 layer of abstraction below CS 61C. I think 16B starts off in a nice way here by introducing transistors with how they are used to implement logic and and how they can influence the speed of a device. Also robotics is a pretty big field in CS that a lot of people want to get into; and 16B prepares you pretty well to start stepping in that direction or other related fields.

You mention EECS, but I'm talking about CS, not EECS. Requiring for EECS makes sense to me, because it's fundamental to the EE side of things. But we have two majors, EECS, and CS, for a reason. 

I agree with linear algebra - it's fundamental to a ton of things that are CS related. But having EE16B serve as "linear algebra" seems fatuous to say the least; just require math 54 or 110 or something instead. Before 2017, Math 54 was allowed to substitute for both EE16A/EE16B.

CS majors don't even need to take machine learning - the point is they can choose which part of CS to explore. EE16B should be another *choice*, if they want to learn more about the hardware side of things.

To decide which courses should be required, the criteria should be how prevalent/needed are with respect to the major itself. CS61C is fundamental in understanding how your code goes down to the assembly level, and programming in C is one of the most salient skills to have. 

CS70 is necessary because problem solving/math ability is needed in a lot of *CS* courses. Which *CS* courses is EE16B needed in? (besides the Linear algebra part which you should be able to just take separately, not with circuits etc). 

It's fine that people change their goals after taking 16B, but then why not make even more classes required, like requiring Data 8 so that people might go more on the data route etc.? You have to analyze the efficacy, and I just don't see EE16B being as fundamental and relevant as the other requirements.

First off 16B is not really about hardware, but about the math behind controls and ML. Just by saying that it makes me think you haven't really understood 16B yet. And linear algebra at 110 is highly abstract/theoretical which is why 16B is there to ground it in application, while 54 covers less linear algebra than 16B. The EECS department also can't expect to use math upper divs to satisfy CS requirements.

And I feel like you're argument is clouded by your personal opinion. You personally may not like robotics, but I personally may not like programming in assembly and C. Does this mean 61C is not important for me and shouldn't be required? I would guess that about the same number of CS majors want to be C programmers as they do robotics engineers, and even more of them want to do ML. EECS 16B is required for EECS 127, CS 189, EECS 106A, EECS 149, helpful for CS 182, CS 184, and these are only the CS classes I'm including. That is plenty enough for it be a required class I think.

Why should 16B be the class about the "math behind ML"? First of all, it's absolutely not about the math behind ML. Saying that is ridiculous IMO, classes that prepare you for ML are the ones Shewchuk rightly lists on his website, Stat 134/140, Math 110, CS70, etc.

EE16B is absolutely an introduction into getting into hardware - learning about circuits and experiments with them is a stepping stone to doing more complex signal processing with hardware. Just because math is sprinkled in to make it an ML-hypebeast class doesn't mean it is or should be required "for ML". 

My point about Math 110 was merely 110 could be used, or 54 could be used. Not that they have to require only 110. 

I mean, my argument *is* my personal opinion, so I'm not sure what point you're trying to make. It's not about whether I like robotics or like assembly, liking it has nothing to do with it. It's about how relevant each class is to the overarching branch of the major. If you don't like CS61C for example, it doesn't mean that should determine whether it should be required or not. My whole point here is that EE16B is more irrelevant than other classes that are required in CS to the overarching CS major umbrella. 

Most of the classes you mentioned for which EE16B is needed for are EECS classes. For the CS ones, EE16B is most definitely not required for CS189 (I mean.. EE16B has circuits in it..). Pure statistics courses like Stat 140 and linear algebra classes like 110 are typically what allow students to succeed in 189. A dispersed, tangentially related sprinkling in EE16B is not.  It also is definitely not for CS182 either. I'm unsure about CS184 because I haven't taken it, but that's *one* class for CS that was named that EE16B is needed for (also I disagree it's needed for EECS127, but I'll concede that even since it's not a CS class).

I agree with Anon Calc that I think you have a misunderstanding of what's taught to you in 16B. The content in 16B really isn't that hardware-related (the labs, maybe, but not the content) and focuses a lot on linear algebra techniques. Oftentimes these techniques are solving how to find the solution/input that minimizes loss, which is then built upon to reach things like ML. I think it would help you have a better understanding if you took a look at the 16B schedule and what they teach in it.

The majority of the class is Robotics, Signal Processing, and Circuits. The Linear algebra techniques done don't make it necessary for CS189, just because a class has some linear algebra, doesn't mean it should be a required course. That's similar to saying Data 100 should be required for CS majors. Again, I'll reiterate my point: EE16B is *not* a class which is necessary for future CS classes.

I agree that the 16B material is not used in the majority of CS upper divs, and can empathize with you quite a bit because I absolutely hated taking 16B (and in fact, almost failed the class). That said, I do think you're still misunderstanding what the course material is about, but I don't know how to explain it to you in a way that will make sense. I'll just leave it at that, maybe you can get a response from faculty that will clear things up.

I really don't have a misunderstanding; I looked over all the notes for past semesters. I understand the goal of making it an ML hypebeast class, but as I said earlier, this isn't the class to take for ML preparation, nor is it a necessary one broadly for other CS classes.

I would say its the opposite of the previous followup. Only about 30% of 16B is circuits and the rest are all important topics for CS majors as controls, linear algebra, and signal processing are essential for anything in robotics and machine learning. I would say 16A is actually more useless since it gives you a very basic intro to linear algebra and has more circuits emphasis than 16B.

Also the same could be said about any lower div class. Why should I take 61C and learn about page tables and virtual memory if all I'm doing is data science or complexity theory for example? Why should I take CS 70 if I just want to be a web dev? The point of lower divs is to show you all the different parts of EECS so you can choose which upper divs you want to take. You don't know what you like until you try it. I know several people who changed their goals after 16B since they really liked the material in the class.

I've wondered this myself as well, especially given the trend of CS majors pushing 16B off until junior/senior year. The main justification that I can find is that concepts like SVD, PCA, pseudoinverses, etc. are often useful ways to solve issues in computer science, and do occasionally come up in the vector-math related CS classes, but are definitely beyond the 16A level. (This is just my takeaway having taken 16A/B and no other EE classes.)

I'm in my last semester as a Senior, and have taken more than 12 upper division EE/CS classes. Granted, they were mostly CS classes, but none of them remotely required the material in EE16B. I understand the purpose of the class - I fully realize it's to give a flavor of mostly EE classes. This is why I've reiterated that for EECS majors, I fully support and agree with the idea that EE16B should be required, because of the reason you mentioned - it serves as a class that gives a flavor of the EE side.

CS majors are not EECS majors, regardless if people like to conflate the two. There are clear differences in how CS and EECS majors on describes, both on their respective webpages, and the other requirements. EE16B should be a choice for those who want to explore the EE side of things. The difference between a choice and a requirement is the requirements are fundamental to the major; which all of the other lower division CS classes are. EE16B Is *not* fundamental to the overarching CS major.

With respect to the leetcode type of people, I fail to see how that is relevant to this. Your argument is that because those people exist, they should be required to take EE16B... because what? You can make the argument with any other class having to do with EE/CS, that it would let them explore other topics. Why not require Data 8, because it would make people explore the Data side? My whole position in these conversations has been let it be a choice. If someone wants to explore the EE side of things, which is not part of the CS major, then by all means. The default shouldn't be "let's require it, if you don't like it, then fine, don't take any more". 

For your last point, I'm unsure why you're talking about "liking" the classes. That detracts from the overall point, none of this is about liking the classes or not. It's about the relevance to the overall major. It's not "complaining" because I don't like the course. It's about whether I think the course itself should be required. I'll remind you, the semester before I joined Cal (Spring 2016), EE16B wasn't required, people could use linear algebra (Math 54) in place of it. 

Even if someone LOVED EE16B with all their heart, I would still argue that EE16B shouldn't be a required course for the CS major. That's fine that you didn't like CS61A/B - but it would be very hard that both of those courses aren't fundamental to being a CS major - basically every CS program has some sort of intro to programming and data structures required for the major. The same can't be said about a similar course to EE16B. 

In summary, I believe that if people want to dip their toes into other tangential fields, by all means. Just don't require it to force the toe-dipping because of some grandiose idea of knowing/pushing what others should dip their toes into.

My example of leetcoding is just an example of a group of students who will find 16B useless because they are better off preparing themselves for technical CS interviews. My argument is that people in the CS majors don't only just consist of people who knew they were going to do CS from the age of 10. The major includes a wide variety of students: those who are CS gods, those who have some experience, and those who don't have any experience whatsoever. So many students in L&S choose to do CS after 61A and switch into it where before they were majoring in something else completely different. For these students, I'd argue its important to give them as much broad knowledge of what CS is related to for them to see what they like, because they have no idea what they like, and that includes low-level stuff. I'd argue that 16B is not even that far off 61C in terms of how low-level it is. You're just learning about how those logic gates are created and that's via transistors and learning how these RC circuits work. 

I don't disagree with your opinion: for several people, it is truly useless. For students like yourself, it seems you never wanted to do EE in your life, and that's fine, it shouldn't be a requirement for you. You also have to consider not everyone in the CS major wants to do pure software CS. Some wants to see what else is in CS and part of it is what 61C and EE16B covers. Those who like computer architecture in 61C would benefit from taking a class like 16B as it leads a path to EECS151/152 and what not. I know plenty of people who are in the CS major who take EE120 and EE123 to learn more about signal processing, which is an important part to ML too.

The only issue I have with your perspective is that you think CS majors should have a set curriculum from A to B and everyone in the CS major should follow a certain path in terms of "usefulness". They are not forcing you to dip your toes in the EE field for fun to see the pain of students struggling to put an op-amp circuit on a breadboard. They letting students see the full stack of the major and from there, students can decide which parts are of interests to them and what they want to pursue in the upperdivs and I believe this "see all" approach is good -- give students a complete view of entire thing, and let them pick what they like. I'm willing to bet there are plenty of CS major students pursuing the EE side of CS in the L&S major and I know a few of them. All of them enjoyed 16B and had it not be a required class, maybe they would have never discovered that they liked the EE side of CS. Would you want these students in CS majors to be filtered out simply because 16B has no relevance to your interest? The reality today is that EE and CS are more intertwined than we all think. Having additional knowledge of an extra stack below 61C doesn't hurt -- now students know it exists and if they don't like it, then just dont go into the stack.

I agree with the Anon. Helix. I was doing purely the CS side of the major for the majority of my undergrad life with doing the bare minimum of EE side (i.e., literally just its lower div class to graduate). Thanks to taking those EE classes, I remember and actually use them when I return to help out on the EE courses as a staff such as EE16B and EE123 (-cough who am I-) despite being originally pure CS. It helps me broaden my field in CS with EE (that I originally don't want to see). I am glad that they add the requirement; otherwise, anyone would pretty much forget about the EE side.

Having taken a wide range of upper division EECS classes and been a TA for 16B, I think you fundamentally misunderstand what the purpose of the class is. Because EECS and CS majors have upper divisions that pretty much overlap and lower divisions are usually taught in a way that prepares you for the upper division, 16B tries (although sometimes logisitically its a mess), to give students a flavor of a bunch of classes in the upper divisions in the EE side of things. 

Module 1 gives you a flavor of EE105, EE130. Module 2 gives you a flavor of EECS128, EE120, EECS106A. Module 3 gives you a flavor of CS189, EECS127. 

Some students have been coding since idk, 10 years old? They already know they want to do CS and wanna leetcode their way into SWE. If the entire CS major was comprised of students of this type, then yes, EE16B is pretty much a useless class for them because none of these upper divs are of any interest to them. Since the CS major is such a broad field in general, there are people who are CS majors after coming to Cal with no clue what to do in CS (and having 0 experience) and 16B is a gentle introduction to saying that there are things beneath a computer called circuits that may be interesting to you. If it is interesting, then here are classes you can take. If not, then thats fine. 

You seem to be fixated in that every lower division class should be geared towards a CS orientated mindset when in reality lower division class serves as survey of the specifics upper divisions that you may be interested in. Not everyone will like every lower division. I personally found 61A/B to be extremely boring so I don't really take upper divisions in the CS side. Many of my friends found EE16A/B to be not their thing, so they don't take EE. But I dont complain about taking 61A/B -- at least now I know I don't like data structures and will not do SWE as my job. My friends don't complain about taking 16B either because now they know they truly dislike circuits. Knowing what you don't like is as powerful as knowing what you like, especially for someone who just started to dip their toes into the CS field, or actually in any field.

I agree with your perspective and resonate with it. I've also taken Math 110/CS189, and am currently doing EE16B - thankfully they allow P/NP this semester, and I'm doing the lite lab as you suggest. My perspective on this is informed by my experience at Berkeley with the CS major, as is everyone's.

I totally agree Math 54 covered Linear Algebra better than 16A, as I was also in it for a while as well. Based on the classes I've taken, it just feels to me like EE16B is the "odd one out" in the CS major curriculum, like a stone thrown in a moving wheel type of thing.

Your reasoning for why they required it 2017 and on makes sense - the instructors in EE seem to really want more people to get into it.

How did you feel EE16B did in terms of covering ML? I've read the notes on those topics over break, and it really seems to me like other classes are better suited for preparation for CS189, as EE16B seems like cursory, almost half-hearted grazing over ML stuff.

I think EE16B is like somewhere between poor and just ok for covering ml? It's just ok as a prereq, but you would get more out of Stat 134/140/EECS126 or EECS127 in terms of ML math, and obviously 189 is the course you wanna take to cover ML (I recommend shewchuk unless you are hardcore about math)

<md>EECS16B was probably the only class I actively disliked that I had to or ended up taking, and probably the class I regret taking the most simply because it was a waste of time and energy for me. 

For me, Math 54 covered linear algebra better than EECS16A (I was in both for a couple of weeks, and looked over the rest of the 16a material), and weirdly enough some semesters (eg, fa19) of EECS16A didn't even cover diagonalization. For some reason, the homeworks were much harder in eecs16a, a distraction I didn't need as a first semester freshman who wants to declare CS, and focused most of my time on doing well in CS61A.

By the time I took 16B, which was my last semester, I had math 110/cs 189 under my belt so I got even less out of it then if I took it earlier in my undergrad career. 

Now if I wanted to learn about robotics or signals, I would take one of the wonderful EE/EECS upper divs, and it does seem like I can take classes like EE120, EE123, EECS C106 without taking EECS16A/B. I wish I could have taken one of those classes instead of EECS16B. 

My plan for EECS16B was to just do the bare minimum to pass and scrape by with a D- I need my last semester, since at that point my last semester grades don't matter.

Here is my opinion/advice, especially those who are just interested in software, put EECS16B off until your last semester, hope there is a no lab/lite lab option, or take it when there is a no lab/lite lab option and don't let it get in the way of your learning from classes you actually want to take. 

I even heavily considered dropping CS for math/data science my very last semester after I had used up enrollment priority that is granted in cs upper divs just to avoid taking EECS16B.

TL; DR: not a fan of 16b

The course staff are really great in 16B tho and they are trying.

Here is why I think EECS16B is required. Policitics from faculty who want more ee/eecs representation and to convince a small percentage of freshman who take 16 series to pursue more ee/eecs courses. Why they couldn't just have CS majors take another CS class, idk.

</md>

and then there are people like me who did extremely above average in cs70 without having taken ee16a or any math higher than ap calculus. Mathematical maturity is a load of gatekeeping bs lmao, idk why i have to take ee16ab as a declared student in l&s cs

Hey Anon, I can give you a different perspective on the importance of EE16B. I think another practical reason why the course is required is because it is recommended to take EE16A + EE16B early in order to build "mathematical maturity", which then smooths the transition to CS 70. You can disagree on its effectiveness, but 61A, 61B, and 61C don't really involve much math at all (but of course are still fairly rigorous/difficult). Getting some more practice manipulating symbolic equations/being introduced to proofs before CS 70 is helpful, and of course both EECS and CS majors have to take that course.


Also it seems like the main issue you have with 16B is "relevance." I think this is where I would actually agree with you. Even the most "relevant" topics like PCA, SVD, Spectral Theorem, DFT, etc. are probably irrelevant to the CS major that has no interest in algorithms or ML (broadly speaking); however, because most EECS/CS majors are actually interested in both of these topics it behooves the department to make this a part of the official curriculum and put their own spin on the material. Also I think 16B did a good job of preparing for ML, although classes like 126/127 are more useful.


Also EE16A + EE16B are designed to cover Math 54 through applications, where the application highlights the underlying/central linear algebra concept (like OMP and least squares, for example). I personally transferred to Berkeley and ended up taking a linear algebra course at community college as well as EE16A, EE16B, Math 110, and CS 189; I found EE16B gave me a completely fresh perspective on linear algebra (shout out to Spring 2019 Sahai lectures, especially with the controllable canonical form derivation -- seriously check out all his lectures from Spring 2019, really great stuff; roughly weeks 4-6, CCF is Lecture 6B I believe). However I did take Math 110 at the same time and CS 189 after, so perhaps that might have skewed my opinion.
For CS/DS majors (i.e not EECS) Math 54 + Math 110 seems like a much better combo than the 16AB series.

history.content: To build mathematical maturity and develop an appreciation for the broad fields in EECS

children.subject: Great answer and great insights!

Ex 16B TA for 4 semesters here, some of you might know who I am. 

Over four semester of teaching, I'll say that the biggest problem with 16B is its lack of a unified vision and the fact that it's trying to do too much. In its early stages, EE16B was created as to replace the intro EE 20/40 series which covered Signals (20) / Circuits (40) and to give a more modern take on topics in EE/EECS. However, somewhere along the way, it also tried to teach all of the concepts in Math 54 and do some mathematical training for CS 70 and this is where things start to fall apart.

So what is the point of EE 16A/B? Depending on who you ask, you'll get a different response. Most of the EE faculty seem to think that it's supposed to be the replacement to 20/40. Some say that it's a survey course of a hodgepodge of topics, others say that it's meant to teach fundamental Linear Algebra Concepts, and some even call it an introductory ML class. This also makes each semester so radically different since faculty all have different takes on this as well. Personally, I'm of the opinion that it should a survey course that teaches foundational concepts in EE. 

A bit of history on 16A/B

In its infancy EE16A was arguably one of the hardest lower-div courses relative to the amount of knowledge you had. CS 162/189 may be hard but EE16A three months out of high school was something else and much more difficult than Math 54. It was all of the Lin Alg in Math 54 + a module on circuits + applications of Lin Alg. 16B on the other hand was still difficult but had a much more satisfying payoff for the students who did well in 16A and maybe took Math 54 before as well (back when it was required).

However, they started to tone down 16A for good reasons, and cut material but may have over corrected a bit too much so that now Math 54 is now much more comprehensive than 16A when it comes to Linear Algebra. The worst part of this entire situation is that all the fundamental Lin Alg concepts that 16A used to teach such as Change of Basis, Diagonalization, Gram-Schmidt were all now 16B's responsibility. 

Somewhere along the way, 16B also became way too mathematical, probably in its vision to be support courses to CS 70. Part of the magic of 16B was to think like an Electrical Engineer and find smart solutions to hard problems. However, once it became EECS 16B, (in its effort to appeal to CS majors? idk) tried to do some ML, the course stopped becoming an Electrical Engineering course.

Why do CS majors need it?  EE and CS are quite related fields and some universities, Berkeley included, choose to have EECS departments. CS majors at other universities have to usually take on EE, Physics, or even Chemistry simply because CS is a technical field. I personally believe these classes exist to make you a rounder and better educated person. However, it's definitely also a political issue since some faculty believe there is only one straight path to learning and 16B is on that path.

Will 16B be useful in my career post-college? Maybe not, but I could say the same for other EECS courses as well. That being said, the class has good moments and valuable insights despite its poor execution. Unfortunately the magic of 16B has faded over the semesters and some of the favorite topics got cut from the class in favor of teaching all the stuff 16A didn't teach. IMO just bring back Math 54 and 16B can at least try to be great again.

What to take out of 16B? It really depends on your background:

  • If you're a 2nd semester senior, planning on doing work in Software Engineering building Web Apps or BeanFactories all day, probably nothing. Just stop complaining and pass the class lol
  • If you're looking to do stuff in Data Science / ML I'd recommend taking Math 110 before or concurrently since the class does have a lot of good Lin Alg applications. 
  • If you want to do stuff in Computer Hardware, definitely focus on the circuits portion; though 16B Circuits have literally turned into Systems Theory as opposed to practical skills, rip transistors :(
  • If you wanna work on robotics, the middle half on Controls is pretty good though 16B somehow manages to teach modern Control Theory past EE128 as opposed to Classical Control.
  • If you want to do EE, then don't be discouraged if you didn't like this class or 16A, even I don't consider 16B to be true EE anymore. Upper div EE's are pretty fun and much less crowded than CS classes :)

history.content: This was changed in 2017; I'm wondering why. It makes sense why EECS majors needs to take it (the EE part), but CS majors? Seems arbitrary, and annoying.
history.subject: Why do CS majors need to take EE16B
